This is in contrast to the idea that divorce in South Africa is a devastating experience that will result in a life sentence of debt, resentment and hardship for both spouses, as well as their children. The South African law of divorce itself, as well as the culture in which South African women live and what their own expectations are of a successful relationship, play important roles in how divorce and its related processes are perceived and experienced. Until the 1990s, divorce had a negative connotation for many women. It was synonymous with a failure in the marriage, it was associated with loss and grief, it was synonymous with destitution and unemployment and it was linked to a life of dependency. The 1990s, however, have seen a shift in these perceptions of divorce, particularly due to the impact of the 1996 Matrimonial Property Act and the introduction of no-fault divorce, one of the most progressive laws in the world. The introduction of maintenance legislation in 1998, which has given South African women the right to maintain a reasonable and secure standard of living, and the commissioning of research on the psychology of divorce in South Africa in 1998, have also assisted greatly in changing the perception of divorce and the divorce process.
